bibl.title: John Leonard v. State of Washington. Writ of Habeus Corpus.
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image.

msIdentifier.repository: National Archives and Records Administration, Seattle Branch, Washington
msIdentifier.collection: RG 21 US Circuit Courts, Western District of Washington, Seattle; Law Register Northern Division, 1890-1901, vol 1

div1.p: IN THE CIRCUIT COURT OF THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON. NORTHERN DIVISION.
IN THE MATTER OF THE APPLICATION OF JOHN LEONARD FOR A WRIT OF HABEAS N O T I C E. CORPUS.

To R. A. Simms, Sheriff of Whitman County, State of Washington. You will please take notice hereby that John Leonard is now in your custody, duly petititoned the United States Circuit Court for Writ of Habeus Corpus, seeking relief thereupon and
Whereas, the said Writ and relief was denied, and whereas, said petitioner duly moved for a Writ of appeal and for the transfer of his whole cause to the Supreme Court of the United States and

Whereas, the said cause came on for argument as to the granting of the said appeal and the transfer of the whole cause to the Appellate Court, and was heard upon the 22nd day of June, 1897 by the Honorable C. H. Hanford, Circuit Judge. and

Whereas, after hearing said application Order of Appeal was duly granted and the said cause was so order ed transferred to the Supreme Court of the United States and full copy of the aforesaid proceedings and the orderallowing said appeal, being duly certified, is hereunto annexed for your information and advice and
Whereas, under the Revised Statutes of the United States being the Laws of the United States particularly Section 766 of the Revised Statutes reads as follows, to-wit:

Section 766. "Pending the proceedings of appeal in the cases mentioned in the three preceeding sections, and until final judgement therein, and after final judgment of discharge, any proceeding against the person so imprisoned or confined or restrained of his liberty, in any State Court, or by or under the authority of any
State, for any matter so heard and determined, or in process of being heard and determined, under such Writ of Habeus Corpus, shall be deemed null and void. *and

Whereas, the Supreme Court of the United States In Re Jugiro 140 United States 295 construing the said Section defined the same to mean, "in cases where the appellant was held in custody under the authority of the State Court, or by authority of a state, to stay the hands of said Court or state, while the question a s to whether his detention was in violation of the Constitution, laws, or treaties of the Unted States was being examined by the courts of the United States having jurisdiction in the premises, which said decision is more fully referred to in the case of In Re. M'Kane 61 Fed. 205 where it was held to mean that until final decision in the Supreme Court of the United States no disturbance of the condition of the person as he was at the time of the denying of the Writ can in any wise be had.

Therefore, you are hereby notified that you are to hold possession or custody of the said Petitioner John Leonard now in your keeping at Coalfax, in the County of Whitman, State of Washington in such manner as to your discre t ion shall seem meet and proper in no wise assuming for any cause to execute any sentence of death whatsoever upon the said Petitioner John Leonard and you will be duly notified of any further proceeding in the premises.
You will please govern yourself accordingly.
John F. Dor J. E. Fenton Del Leary Smith UNITED STATES OF AMERICA DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, COUNTY OF WHITMAN.
